awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Coordination Polymer Superlattices with Tailored Properties through Chemical Vapor Deposition Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract
Coordination polymers are versatile materials that are currently used to filter pollutants, store energy, and convert raw materials into useful chemicals. Recently, there has been great interest in using the extensive structural and chemical tunability of these materials to make a new generation of electronic devices, such as switches, sensors, and smart energy storage systems. However, the poor electrical performance of these materials, and a lack of synthetic methods capable of creating desired material properties has slowed progress. This CAREER project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, addresses these challenges by developing new methods to grow high quality crystalline coordination polymers from the gas phase. Furthermore, this proposal addresses the need to improve the electrical performance of these materials by creating a new material architecture called a superlattice, which is composed of single crystal sheets of various coordination polymers stacked on top of one another. The composition, structure, and layering of the individual sheets can be controlled. Because structure and function are so tailorable in the superlattice, it has the potential to support enhanced and novel properties, allowing it to exceed the performance limits of conventional polymers and solid-state materials.  This research can enable technological advances in energy storage and conversion, and spawn a new generation of filters, actuators, sensors, and optical/electronic devices. Many of these technologies can be used to assure the sustainability and improved welfare of society. The research innovations and methods used in this research provide a multitude of student training opportunities in the synthesis, structure-property determination, and application of materials. In addition to the research objectives described in this proposal, the principal investigator is introducing two education and outreach activities: a podcast channel focused on materials science topics, and an online crowd-sourced database that curates materials synthesis protocols. These activities aim to increase the participation of under-represented minorities in STEM fields and to build a research infrastructure to accelerate the dissemination and verification of research protocols. 

Technical Abstract
Coordination polymers (CPs) can be designed to express a diverse array of structures, porosities, and chemistries rendering them useful for applications in energy storage, separations, and catalysis. However, CPs with more complex functionalities and responsive properties are desired if they are to be successfully integrated into electronic devices. The principal hypothesis of this project, supported by a CAREER award through the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, is that a CP superlattice can support complex, multivariate, and responsive properties. A superlattice comprising layered two-dimensional CP crystal lattices is an attractive architecture, because its inherent hierarchies of structure and composition can be tailored to promote desired or emergent physical properties. This CAREER project addresses the development of chemical vapor deposition methods for the tailored synthesis of CP superlattices and the study of these materials' dynamic and responsive properties. Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) is introduced as a strategy for the preparation of high-quality crystalline CP superlattices.  The project focuses on three core objectives. First, the scope and mechanism of chemical vapor deposition synthesis of CP superlattices are being established.  Second, transport studies conducted on devices fabricated on single crystals of CP superlattices are being used to elucidate their electronic properties. Third, heterostructured CP superlattices with multivariate and responsive properties are being developed and their potential to surpass the performance limits of conventional bulk 3D materials is being determined.  In addition to the research objectives of this project, the principal investigator has introduced two education and outreach activities: a podcast channel focused on materials science topics, and an online crowd-sourced database that curates CVD synthesis protocols. These activities aim to increase the participation of under-represented minorities in STEM fields and to build a research infrastructure to accelerate the dissemination and verification of research protocols.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project was focused on developing new synthesis and characterization methods for a class of materials called metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). MOFs have long been explored and used for gas storage, catalysis, and other energy sustainability missions. In our work, we focused on developing gas-phase synthesis techniques enabling the growth of two-dimensional (2D) sheets of these MOFs. The crystals of these MOFs are 2D in the sense that they are one crystallographic unit cell thick in the out-of-plane direction (several atoms thick), but can extend a considerable distance (many micrometers) in the x-y plane. The electronic and optical properties of these 2D MOFs, especially when layered with other 2D materials, render them promising quantum platforms whose features promise to revolutionize computation, health care, sensing, and energy research.

With respect to intellectual merits, our key outcomes from this funded project centered on the following. First, we made major strides in the synthesis and spectroscopy of 2D MOFs (Fig. 1A). We first showed that a Mo2(isonicotinate)4 paddlewheel cluster can be assembled from the solution-phase into a one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer. This 1D chain has an electronic structure comprised of dimer-like MLCT states arising from a lifting of the degeneracy of monomer orbitals due to their altered symmetry in the 1D chain. Next we demonstrated the first gas phase synthesis of both 1D coordination polymer and 2D MOF lattices using a true chemical vapor deposition (CVD) process. In this approach, the aforementioned Mo paddlewheel clusters sublime, deposit, and then spontaneously arrange into lattices that can assume different topologies. A true CVD-based approach has many advantages, not the least of which is the greater control one can exert over the phase and quality of the grown MOF crystals. Notably, our process can be used to prepare either monolayer MOF crystals or thin films of exceptionally uniform thickness across 1000s of µm2.

Second, we developed new approaches for the fabrication of MOF-based electronic devices and used these to interrogate key transport properties of our 2D MOFs (Fig. 1B). Our measurements on isolated single crystals allow us to probe the electronic transport features intrinsic to the MOF. Moreover, measurements on 2D monolayers provide an opportunity to identify how the electronic, mechanical, and catalytic properties of molecular frameworks change as one approaches the 2D limit. We showed through single-crystal two-terminal devices fabricated to our Mo-based MOF that it undergoes a 30 fold increase in conductivity commensurate with the 1D to 2D phase transition. We also fabricated field-effect transistor devices to our 2D MOF and showed that our 2D Mo-based MOFs have appreciable conductivities of ∼1 mS cm–1 and exhibit p-type channel behavior.

Third, we explored how energy and charge transfer between 2D semiconductors and ordered molecular lattices can be tuned and utilized for energy conversion applications (Fig. 1C). We focused our attention on a structure comprised of 2D WSe2 (a 2D semiconductor) merged with a thin-film of rubrene doped with 1% dibenzotetraphenylperiflanthene (DBP). The WSe2 exciton emission lifetime is significantly reduced to 350 ps in the presence of the heterointerface and is attributable to exciton energy transfer which then drives triplet-triplet fusion giving rise to the upconverted emission within the DBP-doped rubrene layer. Notably, our platform appears to be at least 5 times more efficient at photon upconversion than structures using quantum dot triplet sensitizers.

The efforts described above yielded 10 publications in high-quality and high-impact journals.

With respect to broader impacts, our key outcomes enhanced the scientific community’s basic understanding of crystal growth phenomena and led to the discovery of new properties in 2D MOF superlattices. The research led to 10 impactful publications, many public presentations, the robust training of students and postdoctoral fellows, and spawned new independent and collaborative research endeavors. Our efforts proposed to develop infrastructure for maintaining 2D materials synthesis databases. Moreover, the research accomplished through this CAREER grant inspired many core research objectives which were proposed in a recent NSF MRSEC proposal for which I served as PI for one of the three IRGs.

Critically, this grant supported the research efforts of 5 graduate students and 1 postdoctoral fellow. The research conducted under this grant also provided crucial content for well over 30 seminars and conference presentations over five years and impacted not only the 2D materials and MOF research communities, but also broader society. The studies described above will pave the way for the preparation of advanced active devices such as transistors, sensors, and actuators from 2D molecular frameworks. More broadly, our work has the potential to stimulate new generations of measurement and analysis tools that leverage quantum phenomena to achieve signal detection and manipulation at ultra-high sensitivities. Beyond science and technology, the research conducted as part of this award contributed to educating the public, enhancing public engagement with science and with critical thinking, and safe-guarding our environment.


Last Modified: 05/31/2024
Modified by: Thomas Kempa

(B) 1�3: FET devices of our MOFs. (C) 1�3: Efficient photon upconversion in 2D WSe2:rubrene
